results.title: Germ art
results.brief_description:
Two germs are creating their graffiti in a bathroom when a big germ accidently falls on their work of art.
Music and sound design by Kit Webster.

results.title: Rome
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Practical guide to Europe”.
Presented by John Guerrasio, this is an ideal video for intending travelers to Rome (or Italy generally). Tips and practical advice is given as to accommodation, transportation, places to eat, historical sites to visit, seasonal times to avoid, and suggestions of where to go and what to do whilst in Rome. Also provides a map pointing out the location of major sight-seeing destinations, what to do and what not to do to in respect of Italian culture and customs, and generally assist you in making your visit to Rome an enjoyable experience.

results.title: Paris
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Practical guide to Europe”.
A practical guide for anyone intending to travel to Paris. Highlights the major cultural attractions, historical districts and shopping precincts. Provides advice on public transport options and locating suitable accommodation. Offers tips on visiting galleries and museums during free or quiet periods. Suggests where to eat and what you should expect to pay. Includes the Eiffel Tower, the Louvre, Disneyland, Fountainbleau and Versailles. Presented by John Guerrasio.

results.title: Alvar Aalto: technology and nature
results.creator_credit: Ywe Yalander, BBC Wales, WNYC-TV (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and Oy Yleisradio Ab Svenska TV-enheten
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Born in Finland, Alvar Aalto (1898-1976) was one of the greatest architect and industrial designers of the 20th century. As a young man he rejected the ideals of art nouveau movement, preferring instead to follow his interests in functionalism. As a humanitarian he felt that democracy would be achieved by the mechanisation and standardisation of building practices, being the only way to give more to man. He also recognised the paradox of this and was to forever learn from nature, believing it to be the symbol of freedom. His architecture was widely accepted due to his success in marrying nature with art, man and mass production. But for Aalto, it was nature that was the great teacher, and nature that would provide the greatest inspiration to his work. Forever being influenced by the forests and nature broadly, his buildings would echo the elegance and asymmetry that expresses a natural order. Aalto’s humanitarian interests meant that the function of the building was always directed by the needs of the users. This earned Aalto lasting respect for his designs (i.e the Paimio Sanatorium has long been praised as one of the greatest buildings of the 20th Century), providing many humanitarian solutions to architectural problems. Aalto rejected synthetic materials and plastics, calling them, “drugstore architecture”, and preferred to use natural materials such as; wood, brick, stone, glass and ceramic tile. Aalto invested his interest in these materials and design to develop furniture and fittings to complete the interiors of his buildings. Aalto was most known in his industrial design for laminating and bending layers of birchwood to create bent wood furniture, a technique that has come to symbolise his home region.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ywe Yalander, BBC Wales, WNYC-TV (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and Oy Yleisradio Ab Svenska TV-enheten

results.title: Rock U.S.A. Part 1
results.brief_description: Part one of a two-part series. Presents an overview of rock music throughout America featuring a strange mixture of artists including early footage of Blondie (Debra Harry) and raw and energetic performances by the Dead Boys, Heart, Mother’s Finest and Southside Johnny and the Asbury Jukes.
